intro: Streptanthus hispidus, commonly known as the hairy whitlow grass, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes mustard and cabbages, and is characterized by its small, white or pale yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and has hairy, lance-shaped leaves. It produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain several seeds, which are dispersed by wind. Streptanthus hispidus is often found in open woodlands and along coastal areas.
